key_insight: Pretrained vision-language models can serve as reliable perceptual judges, predicting human binary preferences and enabling image compression models to be trained and evaluated in a human-aligned way.
problem_solved: Traditional distortion metrics (e.g., MSE, PSNR) do not align well with human perception and prior perceptual losses require large-scale psycho-visual labeling; this work provides an alternative judge that better matches human preference signals.
method: Apply state-of-the-art vision-language models to compare reference vs. compressed images and produce pairwise preference or quality scores.
Convert VLM-derived judgments into a training/evaluation signal (e.g., differentiable loss or ranking objective) to optimize compression models for human-aligned quality.
Validate alignment by comparing VLM judgments against human preference data and standard distortion metrics on compression benchmarks.
impact: Allows practitioners to train and evaluate compressors that prioritize perceived image quality with less reliance on bespoke human-label datasets, improving real-world visual fidelity and user satisfaction.
visual_elements: Pipeline diagram: image encoder/compressor → compressed image vs. reference → VLM judge → loss/feedback loop to compressor
Bar/line chart: correlation between human preference, VLM judgments, and traditional metrics (MSE/PSNR/FSIM)
Side-by-side image grid: examples of compressions ranked by MSE vs. VLM preference vs. human votes
Iconography: AI 'judge' gavel or scale weighing a camera/image and a human silhouette to symbolize alignment
paper_title: VLIC: Vision-Language Models As Perceptual Judges for Human-Aligned Image Compression
paper_authors: Kyle Sargent, Ruiqi Gao, Philipp Henzler, Charles Herrmann, Aleksander Holynski
